description: Origin uncertain, but probably from a frequentative form of Middle English *cudden, cuththen, keththen (“to embrace”), a variant of cuthen, kuthen, kithen (“to be familiar with, make known”), from Middle English cuth, couth (“known, familiar”), equivalent to couth +‎ -le. Cognate with Middle Dutch kudden (“to come together, flock together”). More at couth.

entries.meaning: A snuggle; an affectionate embrace, often given to family members and close friends.
examples: Give me a cuddle, Paul, it'll cheer you up.

verbs.description: cuddle (third-person singular simple present cuddles, present participle cuddling, simple past and past participle cuddled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To embrace affectionately; to lie together snugly.
examples: The young lovers cuddled on the couch.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cradle in one's arms so as to give comfort, warmth.
examples: She cuddled the infant before bedtime.
I'm cold; can you roll over here and cuddle me, honey?

entries.meaning: To lie close or snug; to crouch; to nestle.
examples: She cuddles low behind the brake; / Nor would she stay, nor dares she fly.
